Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions NASA: Collaborative Research: The biogeography and evolution of drought tolerance in grasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Drought is a pervasive factor that structures grasslands worldwide. Yet little is known about the genetic basis of drought tolerance, how drought-tolerance has evolved, how it is distributed geographically, and what its potential role is in determining future grassland productivity. In this research, the investigators will determine physiological drought tolerance and associated anatomical and physiological traits for 400 species of grass distributed across eight major evolutionary groups and broad geographic and environmental ranges. To better understand the genetics of grasses, gene expression will be examined as well as root and leaf anatomy, morphology, and physiology. With new sequence data complementing current efforts, the phylogenetic relationships among the 400 species and their environmental niche spaces will be determined. The research will also parameterize models of global productivity in the context of drought, coupling data on drought tolerance with gas exchange and environmental data, which will be critical in modeling responses of vegetation to future climate change.

Understanding the different dimensions of drought tolerance and photosynthesis will contribute broadly to our understanding of grasslands in a way that could impact everything from crop selection to predictions of future global function. Additionally, this project will recruit underrepresented individuals at the graduate and post-doctoral level, will contribute to multiple public datasets, and will develop educational materials such as a temporary exhibit on the phylogeny of grasses and grass roots to the new Flint Hills Discovery Center in Manhattan, KS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grasses are the predominant plant form on approximately a quarter of Earth’s vegetated land surface and consist of about 12,000 species in the plant family Poaceae. Grasses have tremendous economic importance, with cultivated crops such as rice, wheat and maize providing > 50% of the human dietary energy budget. Grasses additionally serve as a major food stock for domesticated animals, provide fiber used for clothing and housing, and are a major source for biofuels. Grasslands represent an important component of global carbon cycling and projected shifts in climate may impact the ability of grasslands to produce goods and services for human needs. A hallmark feature of most grasslands is periodic drought, and historical climatic drying is thought to be associated with the rise and expansion of grasslands worldwide. Drought, and drought-like conditions associated with changes in climate, also pose one the greatest challenges to agriculturally important crops and the maintenance of important ecosystem functions in intact grasslands such as carbon storage and water cycling.

Research conducted under this award examined the interplay of genetics, traits of functional significance and phylogeny in the evolution and biogeography of drought tolerance in grasses. Greenhouse experiments conducted for grass species selected to represent different major lineages enabled comparison of critical physiological and gene expression changes at multiple time-intervals during increasing water stress and during recovery following re-watering. Extensive surveys across all major lineages in Poaceae of root anatomical structure, leaf shape and 3D photosynthetic cell shape in leaves yielded important insights into the evolution of drought tolerance in specific grass lineages. Intermediate leaf shapes are strongly associated with forest-grassland boundaries, and historically represented an important transition between the wider-leaved forest species and the narrower-leaved and more drought tolerant species of grasslands as different grass lineages adapted to open habitats. Root anatomical traits were found to be largely independent of evolutionary relationships, photosynthetic pathway or habitat. On the other hand, warm season grasses, including the most drought-tolerant lineages, strongly converged on a particular highly lobed and longitudinally elongated 3D photosynthetic cell shape. Extent of lobing varies in cool season/forest grasses, but their photosynthetic cells are wider than those of warm season grasses as seen in cross section.

Broader impacts of this work include the training of 3 postdoctoral researchers, 8 graduate students and 4 undergraduate students in best practice methods of data collection, data analyses and scientific communication through oral presentations and manuscript preparation. A 3D modeling protocol was developed that is now being applied to grass flowers. This project also involved the participation of a high school student from a local public school in Iowa. At the time of writing, 13 peer-reviewed publications have been generated, with multiple additional papers currently in preparation. Additional educational impacts of this project included annual summer workshops held at Kansas State University campus and the local Manhattan KS zoo for elementary and middle school students addressing the dynamics of water transport and usage in plants, and how those dynamics are influenced by different plant architectures and environmental conditions.
